elements.content: The efficient removal of pertechnetate (TcO4 –) anions from liquid waste or melter off-gas solution for an alternative treatment is one of the promising options to manage 99Tc in legacy nuclear waste. Safe immobilization of 99Tc is of major importance because of its long half-life (t 1/2 = 2.13 × 105 yrs) and environmental mobility. Different types of inorganic and solid-state ion-exchange materials have been shown to absorb TcO4 – anions from water. However, both high capacity and selectivity have yet to be achieved in a single material. Herein, we show that a protonated version of an ultrastable zirconium-based metal–organic framework can adsorb perrhenate (ReO4 –) anions, a nonradioactive surrogate for TcO4 –, from water even in the presence of other common anions. Synchrotron-based powder X-ray diffraction and molecular simulations were used to identify the position of the adsorbed ReO4 – (surrogate for TcO4 –) molecule within the framework.
elements.clean_text: The efficient removal of pertechnetate (TcO4 -) anions from liquid waste or melter off-gas solution for an alternative treatment is one of the promising options to manage 99Tc in legacy nuclear waste. Safe immobilization of 99Tc is of major importance because of its long half-life (t 1/2 = 2.13 × 105 yrs) and environmental mobility. Different types of inorganic and solid-state ion-exchange materials  have been shown to absorb TcO4 - anions from water. However, both high capacity and selectivity have yet to be achieved in a single material. Herein, we show that a protonated version of an ultrastable zirconium-based metal-organic framework can adsorb perrhenate (ReO4 -) anions, a nonradioactive surrogate for TcO4 -, from water even in the presence of other common anions. Synchrotron-based powder X-ray diffraction and molecular simulations were used to identify the position of the adsorbed ReO4 - (surrogate for TcO4 -) molecule within the framework.

elements.content: A protonated zirconium MOF was used to adsorb perrhenate ions from aqeous solution in presence of other ions. Synchrotron-based powder X-ray diffraction and molecular simulations confirm the presence of perhenate anion near the cationic metal cluster.
elements.clean_text: A protonated zirconium MOF was used to adsorb perrhenate ions from aqeous solution in presence of other ions. Synchrotron-based powder X-ray diffraction and molecular simulations confirm the presence of perhenate anion near the cationic metal cluster.

elements.content: Ion exchange is a widely used industrial process and an essential component of our day-to-day life. Ion exchange has found application in water purification, semiconductor, pharmaceutical, and a number of other industries. Ion-exchange processes have also found applications in nuclear industries, particularly for radioactive disposal application. For example, several different types of commercial ion-exchange resins have been tested for removal of 99TcO4 – from the nuclear waste stream. 99Tc forms as a major byproduct during plutonium production and is present as 99TcO4 – in significant proportion within the nuclear waste stream. The efficient and cost-effective immobilization of radioactive 99TcO4 – in nuclear waste is important considering its long half-life (2.13 × 105 yrs) and environmental mobility. In particular, the chance of groundwater contamination from TcO4 – is significant because of its high water solubility and ability to propagate through the Earth’s upper crust. Several types of materials have been explored for the effective removal of 99TcO4 – from wastewater, including ion-exchange resins, molecular and supramolecular anionic receptors (e.g., cryptands and calixarenes), and inorganic materials (e.g., layered double hydroxides). However, there remains significant room for improvement in terms of uptake, kinetics, and selectivity.
elements.clean_text: Ion exchange is a widely used industrial process and an essential component of our day-to-day life. Ion exchange has found application in water purification, semiconductor, pharmaceutical, and a number of other industries.  Ion-exchange processes have also found applications in nuclear industries, particularly for radioactive disposal application. For example, several different types of commercial ion-exchange resins have been tested for removal of 99TcO4 - from the nuclear waste stream. 99Tc forms as a major byproduct during plutonium production and is present as 99TcO4 - in significant proportion within the nuclear waste stream. The efficient and cost-effective immobilization of radioactive 99TcO4 - in nuclear waste is important considering its long half-life (2.13 × 105 yrs) and environmental mobility. In particular, the chance of groundwater contamination from TcO4 - is significant because of its high water solubility and ability to propagate through the Earth's upper crust. Several types of materials have been explored for the effective removal of 99TcO4 - from wastewater, including ion-exchange resins, molecular and supramolecular anionic receptors (e.g., cryptands and calixarenes), and inorganic materials (e.g., layered double hydroxides). However, there remains significant room for improvement in terms of uptake, kinetics, and selectivity.

elements.content: To this end, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) can be viable candidates for ion-exchange applications. Ionic MOFs (i-MOFs) are formed because of the presence of extra-framework ions, ionic side chains, or simple stoichiometric imbalance between metal centers and organic linkers. A diverse range of i-MOFs have shown excellent ion-exchange properties for a wide variety of ions under laboratory conditions. However, only a handful of these were tested for their ReO4 – exchange capacity, which is a nonradioactive structural surrogate for TcO4 –. With the discoveries of water-stable, easy-to-synthesize MOFs (e.g., UiO and MIL series, where UiO = University of Oslo and MIL = Material of Lavoisier), it is evident that, through the judicious functionalization of these MOFs, they have excellent potential as ion-exchange materials under “real-life” conditions. In this Communication, we report the ReO4 – exchange properties of a protonated amino-functionalized MOF, UiO-66-NH3 +, in aqueous solution in the presence of other competing anions. To better understand the performance characteristics of this material, we determined the position of the adsorbed ReO4 – anions within the UiO-66-NH3 + pores by synchrotron-based X-ray diffraction (XRD).
elements.clean_text: To this end, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) can be viable candidates for ion-exchange applications. Ionic MOFs (i-MOFs) are formed because of the presence of extra-framework ions, ionic side chains, or simple stoichiometric imbalance between metal centers and organic linkers. A diverse range of i-MOFs have shown excellent ion-exchange properties for a wide variety of ions under laboratory conditions. However, only a handful of these were tested for their ReO4 - exchange capacity, which is a nonradioactive structural surrogate for TcO4 -. With the discoveries of water-stable, easy-to-synthesize MOFs (e.g., UiO and MIL series, where UiO = University of Oslo and MIL = Material of Lavoisier), it is evident that, through the judicious functionalization of these MOFs, they have excellent potential as ion-exchange materials under "real-life" conditions. In this Communication, we report the ReO4 - exchange properties of a protonated amino-functionalized MOF, UiO-66-NH3 +, in aqueous solution in the presence of other competing anions. To better understand the performance characteristics of this material, we determined the position of the adsorbed ReO4 - anions within the UiO-66-NH3 + pores by synchrotron-based X-ray diffraction (XRD).

elements.content: UiO-66-NH2 was synthesized using a reported procedure (Figures S1 and S2). Exposing the MOF to acid can be considered as one of the pathways to facilitate the μ-OH group lability, by converting it to a [μ-OH2]+ moiety, and doing so theoretically enhances the an­(ion)-exchange capabilities of the UiO-66-NH2 framework. Additionally, acid treatment protonates the −NH2 group, which has an acid dissociation constant (pK a) of 5, leading to the formation of a charged NH3 + species (Figure S3).
elements.clean_text: UiO-66-NH2 was synthesized using a reported procedure (Figures S1 and S2). Exposing the MOF to acid can be considered as one of the pathways to facilitate the μ-OH group lability, by converting it to a [μ-OH2]+ moiety, and doing so theoretically enhances the an(ion)-exchange capabilities of the UiO-66-NH2 framework. Additionally, acid treatment protonates the -NH2 group, which has an acid dissociation constant (pK a) of 5, leading to the formation of a charged NH3 + species (Figure S3).

elements.content: To test our hypothesis, an activated sample of UiO-66-NH2 was immersed in a 2 M HCl solution for 4 h under stirring, followed by filtration and air drying. We then assessed the crystallinity of the protonated MOF (UiO-66-NH3 +) sample by performing powder XRD experiments. Close inspection of the obtained pattern (Figure S1) indicates that the crystallinity is retained upon acid treatment. The extent of protonation was estimated by comparing energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy data from as-synthesized UiO-66-NH2 to that from UiO-66-NH3 +. As expected, the latter possesses a higher Cl– content, confirming the presence of an −NH3 +Cl– species (Figure S4). We then determined the ReO4 – adsorption in aqueous solution of activated UiO-66-NH2 and UiO-66-NH3 +. First, identical amounts of both materials were added to standard solutions of ReO4 – for 24 h. Following this, ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectra were collected on the filtered stock solutions. Analysis of the spectra indicates that UiO-66-NH3 + has 50% higher ReO4 – adsorption capacity than its nonprotonated analogue (Figure S5). This observation was confirmed by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) analyses.
elements.clean_text: To test our hypothesis, an activated sample of UiO-66-NH2 was immersed in a 2 M HCl solution for 4 h under stirring, followed by filtration and air drying. We then assessed the crystallinity of the protonated MOF (UiO-66-NH3 +) sample by performing powder XRD experiments. Close inspection of the obtained pattern (Figure S1) indicates that the crystallinity is retained upon acid treatment. The extent of protonation was estimated by comparing energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy data from as-synthesized UiO-66-NH2 to that from UiO-66-NH3 +. As expected, the latter possesses a higher Cl- content, confirming the presence of an -NH3 +Cl- species (Figure S4). We then determined the ReO4 - adsorption in aqueous solution of activated UiO-66-NH2 and UiO-66-NH3 +. First, identical amounts of both materials were added to standard solutions of ReO4 - for 24 h. Following this, ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) spectra were collected on the filtered stock solutions. Analysis of the spectra indicates that UiO-66-NH3 + has 50% higher ReO4 - adsorption capacity than its nonprotonated analogue (Figure S5). This observation was confirmed by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) analyses.

elements.content: We then turned our efforts to measuring the ReO4 – adsorption capacity of UiO-66-NH3 + from aqueous solution. In this study, three important parameters were evaluated: uptake capacity, adsorption kinetics, and anion selectivity. To calculate the total uptake capacity of ReO4 – within the framework, a series of ReO4 – (solution) and UiO-66-NH3 + (solid) mixtures, with ReO4 –/UiO-66-NH3 + molar ratios varying from 1:1 to 1:16, were generated. ReO4 – adsorption was calculated by measuring its solution concentration, by ICP-OES, after exposure to UiO-66-NH3 + for 24 h. a shows that ReO4 – uptake saturates at a ratio of 1:2 after removal of 66% of ReO4 –. The further addition of MOF material did not result in the complete removal of ReO4 – from the solution (a), the reason for which is not clear from these experiments; however, a similar trend was observed in previous reports. The adsorption capacity of ReO4 – as a function of time and % ReO4 – removal were fitted with a Langmuir equation, which shows an expected typical type I adsorption curve (b). The overall capacity of the material (1:2 ratio of ReO4 –/UiO-66-NH3 +) is calculated to be 159 mg/g after 24 h (b). The uptake of ReO4 – in UiO-66-NH3 +Cl– can vary significantly from batch to batch depending on the number of anion exchange sites and the extent of conversion to NH3 +Cl–. For example, the % ReO4 – removal for the batch of material used for a was 67% (compared to 55% in b) at the same 1:2 ratio of ReO4 –/UiO-66-NH3 + and the same 24 h of elapsed time. The overall capacity of ReO4 – loading in UiO-66-NH3 +Cl– is higher than that of layered double hydroxides (80–120 mg/g) but lower than that observed for the silver-based one-dimensional coordination polymer SLUG-21, 602 mg/g. However, the thermochemical stability of SLUG-21 is significantly inferior to that of the UiO-66 series. For example, the zirconium-based MOFs are structurally stable in water, over a wide range of pH and temperature values. Finally, the selectivity of the material toward ReO4 – was tested in the presence of equimolar amounts of common competing anions, such as ClO4 –, NO3 –, SO4 2–, and PO4 3–. The adsorption trend is PO4 3– > SO4 2– ∼ NO3 – ∼ ClO4 – ∼ ReO4 – based on ICP-OES experiments (Table S1). This trend can be understood based on the energetics of the ion-exchange process, which involves substitution of Cl– in the UiO-66-NH3 + structure, solvation of Cl–, and (partial) desolvation of the substituting anion. Density functional theory (DFT) simulations suggest that the exchange of NO3 –, ClO4 –, and ReO4 – is an isoenergetic process and is mainly driven by the concentration gradient (Table S2). We also tested individual solutions of each anion with ReO4 – in a 1:1 ratio to gain insight into the anion-exchange mechanism within the UiO-66-NH3 + pores. In the presence of monobasic and dibasic anions such as NO3 – and SO4 2–, UiO-66-NH3 + can still adsorb ReO4 –, while in the presence of a tribasic anion like PO4 3–, ReO4 – adsorption is minimal (Table S1). This trend is unsurprising given the low charge density of the ReO4 – anion with respect to PO4 3–, manifested by a 319.37 kJ/mol difference in the adsorption energies. It is worth noting that the high solvation energy of multivalent anions suggests that they remain partially solvated during the ion-exchange process. Finally, we tested UiO-66-NH3 + for its ability to abstract ReO4 – under dynamic flow conditions (Figure S6). For this experiment, 50 mg of activated UiO-66-NH3 + was packed in a column, with glass wool support, through which a standard ReO4 – solution was passed. The standard solution and eluent were analyzed using UV–vis spectroscopy and ICP-OES experiments.
elements.clean_text: We then turned our efforts to measuring the ReO4 - adsorption capacity of UiO-66-NH3 + from aqueous solution. In this study, three important parameters were evaluated: uptake capacity, adsorption kinetics, and anion selectivity. To calculate the total uptake capacity of ReO4 - within the framework, a series of ReO4 - (solution) and UiO-66-NH3 + (solid) mixtures, with ReO4 -/UiO-66-NH3 + molar ratios varying from 1:1 to 1:16, were generated. ReO4 - adsorption was calculated by measuring its solution concentration, by ICP-OES, after exposure to UiO-66-NH3 + for 24 h. a shows that ReO4 - uptake saturates at a ratio of 1:2 after removal of 66% of ReO4 -. The further addition of MOF material did not result in the complete removal of ReO4 - from the solution (a), the reason for which is not clear from these experiments; however, a similar trend was observed in previous reports. The adsorption capacity of ReO4 - as a function of time and % ReO4 - removal were fitted with a Langmuir equation, which shows an expected typical type I adsorption curve (b). The overall capacity of the material (1:2 ratio of ReO4 -/UiO-66-NH3 +) is calculated to be 159 mg/g after 24 h (b). The uptake of ReO4 - in UiO-66-NH3 +Cl- can vary significantly from batch to batch depending on the number of anion exchange sites and the extent of conversion to NH3 +Cl-. For example, the % ReO4 - removal for the batch of material used for a was 67% (compared to 55% in b) at the same 1:2 ratio of ReO4 -/UiO-66-NH3 + and the same 24 h of elapsed time. The overall capacity of ReO4 - loading in UiO-66-NH3 +Cl- is higher than that of layered double hydroxides (80-120 mg/g) but lower than that observed for the silver-based one-dimensional coordination polymer SLUG-21, 602 mg/g. However, the thermochemical stability of SLUG-21 is significantly inferior to that of the UiO-66 series. For example, the zirconium-based MOFs are structurally stable in water, over a wide range of pH and temperature values. Finally, the selectivity of the material toward ReO4 - was tested in the presence of equimolar amounts of common competing anions, such as ClO4 -, NO3 -, SO4 2-, and PO4 3-. The adsorption trend is PO4 3- > SO4 2- ~ NO3 - ~ ClO4 - ~ ReO4 - based on ICP-OES experiments (Table S1). This trend can be understood based on the energetics of the ion-exchange process, which involves substitution of Cl- in the UiO-66-NH3 + structure, solvation of Cl-, and (partial) desolvation of the substituting anion. Density functional theory (DFT) simulations suggest that the exchange of NO3 -, ClO4 -, and ReO4 - is an isoenergetic process and is mainly driven by the concentration gradient (Table S2). We also tested individual solutions of each anion with ReO4 - in a 1:1 ratio to gain insight into the anion-exchange mechanism within the UiO-66-NH3 + pores. In the presence of monobasic and dibasic anions such as NO3 - and SO4 2-, UiO-66-NH3 + can still adsorb ReO4 -, while in the presence of a tribasic anion like PO4 3-, ReO4 - adsorption is minimal (Table S1). This trend is unsurprising given the low charge density of the ReO4 - anion with respect to PO4 3-, manifested by a 319.37 kJ/mol difference in the adsorption energies. It is worth noting that the high solvation energy of multivalent anions suggests that they remain partially solvated during the ion-exchange process. Finally, we tested UiO-66-NH3 + for its ability to abstract ReO4 - under dynamic flow conditions (Figure S6). For this experiment, 50 mg of activated UiO-66-NH3 + was packed in a  column, with glass wool support, through which a standard ReO4 - solution was passed. The standard solution and eluent were analyzed using UV-vis spectroscopy and ICP-OES experiments.

elements.content: (a) Adsorption of ReO4 – in UiO-66-NH3 + as a function of the ReO4 –/UiO-66-NH3 + molar ratio. (b) Adsorption of ReO4 – in UiO-66-NH3 +. (The molar ratio was kept constant at 1:2 ReO4 –/UiO-66-NH3 +.)
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Adsorption of ReO4 - in UiO-66-NH3 + as a function of the ReO4 -/UiO-66-NH3 + molar ratio. (b) Adsorption of ReO4 - in UiO-66-NH3 +. (The molar ratio was kept constant at 1:2 ReO4 -/UiO-66-NH3 +.)

elements.content: To understand the ion-exchange mechanism with molecular-level precision, synchrotron-based powder XRD patterns were collected for the parent UiO-66-NH3 + and ReO4 –-loaded UiO-66-NH3 + (Figures S7 and S8 and Tables S3–S5). By comparing the difference density maps, we were able to locate the ReO4 – ion within the MOF pores (, top). The Re atom sits within three benzene rings, along the diagonal line of the cubic cell, approximately 3 Å away from the μ-O atom of the [Zr6O4(OH)4]12+ cluster. However, we were not able to confirm the O-atom positions of ReO4 – because of the low site occupancy (0.1) and the effect of the surrounding water molecules. If we assume that the tetrahedral geometry of ReO4 – binds to the global crystal symmetry, there are only two possible orientations of ReO4 –: (a) an O atom on the diagonal line (of the cubic cell) close to the bridging μ-O atom with three other O atoms away from the cluster; (b) three O atoms oriented toward the cluster and one O atom on the diagonal line away from the cluster (, bottom). According to our DFT simulations, orientation b is 129.29 kJ/mol lower in energy than configuration a and, therefore, is the most probable configuration of adsorbed ReO4 –.
elements.clean_text: To understand the ion-exchange mechanism with  molecular-level precision, synchrotron-based powder XRD patterns were collected for the parent UiO-66-NH3 + and ReO4 --loaded UiO-66-NH3 + (Figures S7 and S8 and Tables S3-S5). By comparing the difference density maps, we were able to locate the ReO4 - ion within the MOF pores (, top). The Re atom sits within three benzene rings, along the diagonal line of the cubic cell, approximately 3 Å away from the μ-O atom of the [Zr6O4(OH)4]12+ cluster. However, we were not able to confirm the O-atom positions of ReO4 - because of the low site occupancy (0.1) and the effect of the surrounding water molecules. If we assume that the tetrahedral geometry of ReO4 - binds to the global crystal symmetry, there are only two possible orientations of ReO4 -: (a) an O atom on the diagonal line (of the cubic cell) close to the bridging μ-O atom with three other O atoms away from the cluster; (b) three O atoms oriented toward the cluster and one O atom on the diagonal line away from the cluster (, bottom). According to our DFT simulations, orientation b is 129.29 kJ/mol lower in energy than configuration a and, therefore, is the most probable configuration of adsorbed ReO4 -.

elements.content: Differential Fourier density map of UiO-66-NH3 + (top right) and UiO-66-NH2 (top left). The blue ball in UiO-66-NH3 + represents Re (bottom) The position of the Re atom with respect to the basic building unit of UIO-66-NH3 + is shown. Color scheme: light blue, Zr; red, O; gray, C; blue, N; green, Re.
elements.clean_text: 2  Differential Fourier density map of UiO-66-NH3 + (top right) and UiO-66-NH2 (top left). The blue ball in UiO-66-NH3 + represents Re (bottom) The position of the Re atom with respect to the basic building unit of UIO-66-NH3 + is shown. Color scheme: light blue, Zr; red, O; gray, C; blue, N; green, Re.

elements.content: In conclusion, we showed that the protonated version of the chemically robust MOF UiO-66-NH2 is capable of adsorbing ReO4 – from an aqueous medium even in the presence of other competing anions. The material has an uptake capacity of 159 mg/g, which is significantly higher than that of traditional inorganic materials such as layered double hydroxides. The position of the adsorbed ReO4 – was determined by synchrotron-based XRD techniques, which show that the adsorbed ReO4 – is present near the [Zr6O4(OH)4]12+ cluster. The acid washing of the parent UiO-66-NH2 likely removed the μ-OH groups, enhancing the nucleophilicity of the metal cluster. Although the selectivity of this material is lower when competing anions (PO4 3–) are present, experiments are in progress to develop and modify material properties to improve the selectivity of ReO4 – over other anions from low activity waste.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we showed that the protonated version of the chemically robust MOF UiO-66-NH2 is capable of adsorbing ReO4 - from an aqueous medium even in the presence of other competing anions. The material has an uptake capacity of 159 mg/g, which is significantly higher than that of traditional inorganic materials such as layered double hydroxides. The position of the adsorbed ReO4 - was determined by synchrotron-based XRD techniques, which show that the adsorbed ReO4 - is present near the [Zr6O4(OH)4]12+ cluster. The acid washing of the parent UiO-66-NH2 likely removed the μ-OH groups, enhancing the nucleophilicity of the metal cluster. Although the selectivity of this material is lower when competing anions (PO4 3-) are present, experiments are in progress to develop and modify material properties to improve the selectivity of ReO4 - over other anions from low activity waste.

cln_elements.content: In conclusion, we showed that the protonated version of the chemically robust MOF UiO-66-NH2 is capable of adsorbing ReO4 – from an aqueous medium even in the presence of other competing anions. The material has an uptake capacity of 159 mg/g, which is significantly higher than that of traditional inorganic materials such as layered double hydroxides. The position of the adsorbed ReO4 – was determined by synchrotron-based XRD techniques, which show that the adsorbed ReO4 – is present near the [Zr6O4(OH)4]12+ cluster. The acid washing of the parent UiO-66-NH2 likely removed the μ-OH groups, enhancing the nucleophilicity of the metal cluster. Although the selectivity of this material is lower when competing anions (PO4 3–) are present, experiments are in progress to develop and modify material properties to improve the selectivity of ReO4 – over other anions from low activity waste.

metadata.title:
Zirconium-Based Metal–Organic Framework for
Removal of Perrhenate from Water
